@dawid22 The original NGP specs are give it roughly 2x the horsepower of the iPhone 4.  Also, a dedicated portable console doesn't have quite the priorities of a mobile phone in terms of portability, not being overly power-hungry, &c.

A slew of previews of both the hardware and games have hit the web, and have been very positive. Also, the system apparently not only boasts full backwards compatibility with PSP games, but will also render them at a higher resolution and enable both analog sticks to be used.
Just read that the VITA will be region free. That's a good start

Which still makes me wonder why the damn 3DS is region locked.

Also: Wake me up when they announce a Persona game for the Vita.

The Vita's screen is stunning, especially when you're looking at a vibrant game like Blazblue. I did find it a little too easy to accidentally activate the rear touch pad. Not a huge inconvenience (it's easy to adjust), but I blew quite a few power-ups in Super Stardust that way.

The front (capacitive) touch screen is a pretty unobtrusive addition. For the most part, I've seen it being used for interface stuff, such as tapping a map icon on the screen. Hardly essential, but sometimes it just seemed more natural to tap the screen for quick access to something. 

The analog sticks are ... about as good as you might expect given the system's size. They feel a little flimsy, and aren't deep enough to match the range of, say, the Dual Shock, though they're certainly better than the PSP's awkwardly placed nubbin. The biggest surprise? The Vita is much lighter than you think.

Graphically, I think "PS3-level" is an exaggeration at this point. Uncharted: Golden Abyss is probably the best looking game so far, and it's not quite up to the level of Uncharted 1.
